qa_pairs.question: How did the economic and political instability of Uruguay during the 1830s-1850s impact the feasibility of establishing a stable monetary system, and what were the consequences of these challenges?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The economic and political instability of Uruguay during the 1830s–1850s, including a chaotic economy, lack of a national currency, and the Great War, significantly hindered the feasibility of establishing a stable monetary system.<cite>[S3][S8]</cite></statement> <statement>Despite these challenges, attempts were made to mint national coins, such as the *Peso del Sitio* and *Sol de cabellera*, but the persistent instability made it difficult to implement a cohesive monetary policy.<cite>[S4][S6]</cite></statement> <statement>The consequences included the continued circulation of foreign currencies (e.g., Spanish, Portuguese, British, and Brazilian coins) until 1893, as well as temporary solutions like the "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires," which were only valued at half their nominal worth due to severe currency shortages.<cite>[S11][S14]</cite></statement> <statement>These challenges highlighted the inability to create a unified national currency, leading to prolonged reliance on foreign money and fragmented monetary practices until later reforms.<cite>[S8][S11]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay


# Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay



The **Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay** includes the coins minted by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay between the years 1840 and 1855 in the national territory. [S2] These coins were minted entirely within the city of Montevideo, first at the "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" owned by a French artisan named Agustín Jouve and later at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* (Montevideo Mint) or *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, which was created for this purpose. [S3] This period in Uruguayan numismatics was immersed in a historical context full of economic problems, a non-existent currency, an economy practically in chaos and a civil war that lasted for years (the Great War). [S4] In spite of these difficulties, several attempts were made to mint a coin that would bear national signs and would be able to put an end to the prevailing chaos, given that up to that moment the currency of all the different regimes that had exercised power in the territory had been in circulation: the Crown of Spain, the Crown of Portugal, the British Empire, the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata and, finally, the Empire of Brazil. [S5] The first national coins were minted in 1839, in the workshop of the engraver Agustín Jouve, followed by the series minted in the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* until 1855, date from which the first coins were minted in foreign mints, thus culminating the classic period of Uruguayan numismatics. [S6] During this period magnificent coins were issued, among them the *Peso del Sitio* and the *Sol de cabellera*, all of which are currently museum pieces or are part of the most important collections in the country, each of them being highly coveted by collectors. [S7] ## Historical context

Since the birth of the new Republic, on August 27, 1828, there were several attempts to create a monetary system that would solve the problem of the circulating currencies in the territory and define a national monetary system with national signs. [S8] However, the economic difficulties of the time and the social situation of the new State made it almost impossible to install an economic-monetary policy that would put an end to the daily difficulties of commerce. [S9] Once independence was achieved, the provisional government of General José Rondeau (October 4, 1828) did not take any monetary measure and allowed the circulation of all the currencies existing in the country at the date of assumption. [S10] The first decisions regarding the monetary aspect were taken in 1829, year in which it was prohibited the introduction of all copper coins coming from abroad into the territory of the Republic. [S11] However, precious metal coins (gold and silver) continued to circulate until 1893 (accepted until then for their intrinsic value), when their circulation was definitively prohibited. [S12] With the arrival of the first Constitutional President of the Republic, General Fructuoso Rivera, important measures continued to be taken, ordering in 1831 the withdrawal of all foreign copper currency. [S13] As a result of these measures, the city suffered a serious lack of foreign currency, so the government began to look for a quick solution to supply the needs of commerce. [S14] A solution to this situation was found by means of the law of March 14, 1831, which provided for the issuance of the currency known as "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires" for half of its written value. [S15] These coins with a value of one tenth of a real were the first coins issued by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay.

qa_pairs.question: What were the primary legal and material challenges faced by the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* during its first period of operations, and how did these challenges influence the characteristics of the coins minted?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* faced legal challenges related to compliance with Laws No. 254 and No. 255 of December 13, 1843, which authorized the issuance of specific coin denominations, including copper and silver coins. These laws mandated the production of 5, 20, and 40 centésimos of real (copper) and Half and One *Peso Fuerte* (silver), shaping the initial coinage framework.<cite>[S37][S38][S39]</cite></statement><statement>Material challenges arose from the Siege of Montevideo, which caused severe scarcity of silver. This led to the collection of impure silver items (e.g., *mates*, spoons, and spurs) from citizens, resulting in the *Peso del Sitio* being minted with silver of 10 1/2 dineros (0.875 fine) and a limited production of around 1,000 coins.<cite>[S67][S68][S69][S70]</cite></statement><statement>The scarcity of materials and the use of modified stamps (e.g., altering 1839 stamps for 1843 coins) influenced coin characteristics. For example, the 20 centésimos of 1843 featured a forced "3" in the date, while the 40 centésimos of 1844 had over 20 variants due to unrecorded stamp usage, reflecting operational constraints.<cite>[S47][S48][S63]</cite></statement><statement>The *Peso del Sitio* was primarily commemorative rather than for circulation, as its minting was restricted by legal prohibitions (e.g., General Oribe’s 1844 decree) and material limitations, emphasizing its symbolic role in national independence.<cite>[S74][S77][S78]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S37] It was created in order to comply with Laws No. [S38] 254 and No. [S39] 255 of December 13, 1843, which empowered the Government to issue coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of real (copper) and Half and One *Peso Fuerte* (silver). [S40] The same day these laws were enacted, the first tests were carried out, minting coins of 20 hundredths of a real. [S41] In spite of this, the institution was officially inaugurated on February 2, 1844, by the then Political and Police Chief of Montevideo, Andrés Lamas, installing itself in a small workshop in the building of the Police Headquarters of the city called *Casa Central de Policía*. [S42] ### First period of issues by the Casa de Monedas

There are two distinct stages in the first period of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which are detailed below. [S43] ### First stage

This stage began with the minting of a 20 centésimos coin on the afternoon of December 13 and lasted until mid-March 1844, when the Mint suspended its activities. [S44] During this period the institution depended on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo and its director was Don Domingo Parpal and minted coins of 20 centésimos of 1843, 5, 20 and 40 centésimos of 1844 in addition to the magnificent piece of the *Peso Fuerte* or *Peso del Sitio*. [S45] All these pieces were made in the workshop located in the *"Casa Central de Policía"*. [S46] #### First issue (20 cent 1843)

Immediately after the promulgation of Law No. [S47] 254 of December 13, 1843, the first trials were carried out by issuing 20 cent coins with the same stamps used by Agustín Jouve in 1839, with the date changed from 1840 to 1843. [S48] The characteristic of these pieces is that since the date was modified, the number 3 appears forced. [S49] These pieces are the first issued by the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S50] | 20 cents of 1843 | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Valoe | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 20 cent. [S51] | N.° 254 of the day December 13, 1843. [S52] | 21,5 grams | 20 - 24,9 grams | Copper | 37 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve (adapted stamps) | 15.000 (approx.) |

* This coin was known by the name of "*Vintén*" which comes from the Portuguese expression "*Vintem*" which corresponds to a coin with the value of 20 réis of copper.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

#### Issue 5, 20, 40 cents of 1844

They were issued throughout the first stage of the Mint. [S53] They were pieces that contributed to give solidity to the development of commerce and helped to put an end to the great shortage of circulating currency that existed in the new Republic. [S54] | **Minting in 1844** | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Value | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 5 cent. [S55] | N.° 254 of the day December 13, 1843. [S56] | 5,38 grams | 5,4 - 5,7 grams | Copper | 24 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve | 6.000 (approx.) |
| 20 cent. [S57] | 21,5 grams | 21 grams | 38 mm | 10.000 (approx.) |
| 40 cent. [S58] | 43 grams | 36 - 42 grams | 38 – 42 mm | 65.000 (approx.) |

* Five different mintages are known for the 5 cent. [S59] piece. [S60] * The 40 cent. [S61] coin was the only one minted at the Mint with this value. [S62] For its minting, a number of stamps were used that have not yet been accurately determined, so that more than 20 variants of this piece are known. [S63] One of these variants is known as the "*Sol de Cabellera*", since on the obverse the face of the sun corresponds to a native with long hair. [S64] Due to its great relief, it is very rare to find specimens in good condition, which makes it a very coveted piece by collectors. [S65] #### *Peso del Sitio* or *Peso Fuerte*

Passage 2:
[S66] This piece is the only silver coin to be minted at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S67] This minting was carried out in an extremely reduced number (a little more than 1,000) due to the scarcity of materials. [S68] This shortage of materials (caused by the Siege of Montevideo) could be overcome because materials were collected inside the besieged square. [S69] *Mates*, spoons, light bulbs, spurs, etc., all made of silver, were collected from the citizens, among them Andrés Lamas himself or personalities such as Giuseppe Garibaldi or Isidoro de María.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ The collected silver, naturally impure, product of the different qualities of silver collected, was analyzed by the expert chemist Professor Julio Antonio Lenoble, who classified the material with a fine 10 1/2 dineros (0.875). [S70] #### Characteristics of the *Peso del Sitio*

| ***Peso del Sitio* o *Peso Fuerte*** | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Value | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 1 peso. [S71] | N.° 254 of December 13, 1843. [S72] | 27 grams | 27 grams | Silver, fine 10 1/2 (*dinero*) | 39 mm | *Cordoncillo* | Agustín Jouve | 1.000 (approx.) |

* Some pieces minted on coins from other countries are known. [S73] * This piece would circulate only in Montevideo since on February 15, 1844, from his headquarters in the Cerrito de la Victoria, General Manuel Oribe (Chief of the forces that besieged Montevideo) prohibits the circulation throughout the territory of the Republic. [S74] It is, without a doubt, one of the most beautiful coins of the Classical Monetary. [S75] It was minted with similar characteristics to those of a Spanish peso. [S76] It is believed that it was minted more as a commemorative element than for circulation. [S77] This idea is based on the good condition in which the specimens have arrived to our time (although some specimens undoubtedly circulated). [S78] The following is a small passage from a speech made by Andrés Lamas to the President of the Republic, Joaquín Suárez, on the occasion of the inauguration of the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S79] > YOUR EXCELLENCY. [S80] Sir: I have the honor to present to Your Excellency the first silver coin destined for circulation, minted at the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S81] This coin, Mr. [S82] President, is monumental, and this monument is unique to this day on the eastern and western banks of the Rio de la Plata. [S83] This coin is the most finished symbol, Mr. [S84] President, of the National Independence. [S85] In all times and in the public law of all nations, the minting of coins has been the highest prerogative of the Independent Empire. [S86] ### Second stage

The *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, once out of operation, continued to depend on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo, until May 27, 1844, when it became dependent on the Ministry of Finance (a position held by Andres Lamas). [S87] On September 20, 1844, Andrés Lamas resigned from the Ministry of Finance due to a series of denunciations he received for irregularities committed in the *Casa de Monedas*. [S88] At the head of this ministry would now be Don Santiago Sayago who would order on October 20 the opening of the mint designating Don Juan de Bernade y Mederos as General Director. [S89] The existing stamps were immediately inspected and found to be in very poor condition, so the Director obtained authorization to have new ones engraved. [S90] During this period only 40 cent coins were issued with a date of 1844 (as was seen previously in issue 40 cent of 1844). [S91] This stage of the *Casa de Monedas* lasted until mid-January 1845, when it was definitively closed and the materials of Agustín Jouve used up to that time were returned. [S92] ### Second period of issues by the *Casa de Monedas*

qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking about the primary legal and material challenges faced by the Casa de Moneda de Montevideo during its first period of operations and how these challenges influenced the characteristics of the coins minted.

First, I need to go through the supporting context provided. The passage mentions that the Casa de Moneda was created under Laws No. 254 and 255 of December 13, 1843. These laws allowed the government to issue specific coins. However, the first tests were carried out the same day, but the institution was officially inaugurated later in February 1844. 

Looking at the first stage, they started minting 20 centésimos coins in December 1843. But there's a mention of the institution depending on the Political Chief of Montevideo and the director being Domingo Parpal. The first coins had issues with the date modification, leading to a forced '3' in the number. That might be a material challenge, like using existing stamps but altering them, which could affect the coin's quality.

Then there's the issue of the Peso Fuerte or Peso del Sitio. The passage states that the minting of this silver coin was limited due to material scarcity, specifically because of the Siege of Montevideo. They had to collect silver items from citizens, which were impure. This scarcity would influence the coin's characteristics, like the metal purity (10 1/2 dineros, 0.875 fine) and the fact that only around 1,000 were made. Also, the Peso del Sitio was mostly commemorative, not for circulation, which might be a legal challenge because of the restrictions on its use.

Another point is the material challenges affecting the 40 centésimos coin. The passage mentions that more than 20 variants exist due to unknown stamps used, leading to different designs like the "Sol de Cabellera." This variability could be due to the limited and possibly inconsistent materials available.

The legal challenges might include the laws that mandated specific coinage, but the material shortages forced adaptations. For example, the Peso del Sitio's limited circulation due to the siege and the legal prohibition by General Oribe. Also, the transition in management from the Political Chief to the Ministry of Finance might have caused operational challenges.

So, compiling this, the primary legal challenges were the laws that required specific coinage, and the material challenges were the scarcity of silver during the siege, leading to impure materials and limited production. These influenced the coins by causing variations in design, limited mintages, and the commemorative nature of some coins like the Peso del Sitio.

qa_pairs.question: How did the transition of administrative control from the Political Chief of Montevideo to the Ministry of Finance impact the operations of the *Casa de Moneda*, and what were the consequences of this shift?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The transition of administrative control from the Political Chief of Montevideo to the Ministry of Finance occurred on May 27, 1844, when the *Casa de Moneda* became dependent on the Ministry of Finance, a position held by Andrés Lamas at the time.<cite>[S87]</cite></statement> <statement>This shift led to significant changes in operations, including the resignation of Lamas from the Ministry of Finance in September 1844 due to denunciations of irregularities at the *Casa de Moneda*.<cite>[S88]</cite></statement> <statement>Following Lamas' resignation, Santiago Sayago took over the Ministry of Finance and ordered the reopening of the mint, appointing Juan de Bernade y Mederos as General Director. The existing stamps were found to be in poor condition, necessitating the engraving of new ones.<cite>[S89][S90]</cite></statement> <statement>During this period, only 40-cent coins dated 1844 were issued, marking a limited production phase compared to the earlier stages.<cite>[S91]</cite></statement> <statement>The second stage of operations concluded with the definitive closure of the *Casa de Moneda* by mid-January 1845, after which the materials from Agustín Jouve were returned.<cite>[S92]</cite></statement>

Passage 1:
[S37] It was created in order to comply with Laws No. [S38] 254 and No. [S39] 255 of December 13, 1843, which empowered the Government to issue coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of real (copper) and Half and One *Peso Fuerte* (silver). [S40] The same day these laws were enacted, the first tests were carried out, minting coins of 20 hundredths of a real. [S41] In spite of this, the institution was officially inaugurated on February 2, 1844, by the then Political and Police Chief of Montevideo, Andrés Lamas, installing itself in a small workshop in the building of the Police Headquarters of the city called *Casa Central de Policía*. [S42] ### First period of issues by the Casa de Monedas

There are two distinct stages in the first period of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which are detailed below. [S43] ### First stage

This stage began with the minting of a 20 centésimos coin on the afternoon of December 13 and lasted until mid-March 1844, when the Mint suspended its activities. [S44] During this period the institution depended on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo and its director was Don Domingo Parpal and minted coins of 20 centésimos of 1843, 5, 20 and 40 centésimos of 1844 in addition to the magnificent piece of the *Peso Fuerte* or *Peso del Sitio*. [S45] All these pieces were made in the workshop located in the *"Casa Central de Policía"*. [S46] #### First issue (20 cent 1843)

Immediately after the promulgation of Law No. [S47] 254 of December 13, 1843, the first trials were carried out by issuing 20 cent coins with the same stamps used by Agustín Jouve in 1839, with the date changed from 1840 to 1843. [S48] The characteristic of these pieces is that since the date was modified, the number 3 appears forced. [S49] These pieces are the first issued by the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. Passage 2:
[S66] This piece is the only silver coin to be minted at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S67] This minting was carried out in an extremely reduced number (a little more than 1,000) due to the scarcity of materials. [S68] This shortage of materials (caused by the Siege of Montevideo) could be overcome because materials were collected inside the besieged square. [S69] *Mates*, spoons, light bulbs, spurs, etc., all made of silver, were collected from the citizens, among them Andrés Lamas himself or personalities such as Giuseppe Garibaldi or Isidoro de María.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ The collected silver, naturally impure, product of the different qualities of silver collected, was analyzed by the expert chemist Professor Julio Antonio Lenoble, who classified the material with a fine 10 1/2 dineros (0.875). * Some pieces minted on coins from other countries are known. [S73] * This piece would circulate only in Montevideo since on February 15, 1844, from his headquarters in the Cerrito de la Victoria, General Manuel Oribe (Chief of the forces that besieged Montevideo) prohibits the circulation throughout the territory of the Republic. [S74] It is, without a doubt, one of the most beautiful coins of the Classical Monetary. [S75] It was minted with similar characteristics to those of a Spanish peso. [S76] It is believed that it was minted more as a commemorative element than for circulation. [S77] This idea is based on the good condition in which the specimens have arrived to our time (although some specimens undoubtedly circulated). [S78] The following is a small passage from a speech made by Andrés Lamas to the President of the Republic, Joaquín Suárez, on the occasion of the inauguration of the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S79] > YOUR EXCELLENCY. [S80] Sir: I have the honor to present to Your Excellency the first silver coin destined for circulation, minted at the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S81] This coin, Mr. [S82] President, is monumental, and this monument is unique to this day on the eastern and western banks of the Rio de la Plata. [S83] This coin is the most finished symbol, Mr. [S84] President, of the National Independence. [S85] In all times and in the public law of all nations, the minting of coins has been the highest prerogative of the Independent Empire. [S86] ### Second stage

The *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, once out of operation, continued to depend on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo, until May 27, 1844, when it became dependent on the Ministry of Finance (a position held by Andres Lamas). [S87] On September 20, 1844, Andrés Lamas resigned from the Ministry of Finance due to a series of denunciations he received for irregularities committed in the *Casa de Monedas*. [S88] At the head of this ministry would now be Don Santiago Sayago who would order on October 20 the opening of the mint designating Don Juan de Bernade y Mederos as General Director. [S89] The existing stamps were immediately inspected and found to be in very poor condition, so the Director obtained authorization to have new ones engraved. [S90] During this period only 40 cent coins were issued with a date of 1844 (as was seen previously in issue 40 cent of 1844). [S91] This stage of the *Casa de Monedas* lasted until mid-January 1845, when it was definitively closed and the materials of Agustín Jouve used up to that time were returned. [S92] ### Second period of issues by the *Casa de Monedas*

qa_pairs.question: How did the 1854-1855 minting efforts differ from the 1840 minting, and what does the presence of the 'Forced' 4 on the 1854 5 centavo coin suggest about the technical or administrative practices of the time?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The 1854-1855 minting efforts differed from the 1840 minting in scale, organization, and technical execution. The 1840 minting faced significant challenges, including copper shortages, limited production (only $500 worth of coins minted instead of the planned $20,000), and reliance on a small workshop, while the 1854-1855 efforts involved larger quantities (e.g., 120,000 5 centavo coins in 1854) and a more structured institutional framework under the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*.<cite>[S26][S27][S28][S29][S96][S98]</cite></statement><statement>The presence of the "Forced" 4 on the 1854 5 centavo coin suggests that the minting process may have reused older dies from previous years (e.g., 1840 or 1844), indicating either technical limitations in die production or administrative shortcuts. This anomaly implies that the minting authorities prioritized efficiency over precision, potentially due to resource constraints or a lack of standardized procedures at the time. The 1854 5 centavo coin’s characteristics, such as its weight and module, closely align with those of the 1840 5 centavo, further supporting the hypothesis that existing dies were repurposed. This practice highlights the technical and administrative challenges of the period, where improvisation and reuse of equipment may have been necessary to meet demand.<cite>[S102][S103]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S16] These measures were not enough to alleviate the shortage situation, despite the fact that the number of coins issued was considerable (2 million), and led the Government to take new measures in 1839 by means of Law No. [S17] 208 of June 20. [S18] This law creates a new monetary system in which the *Peso* or *Patacón* is divided into 8 reales and each one of them into one hundred centésimos (a system that will last until 1862) and authorizes the issuance of coins of 5 and 20 centésimos (for an amount of $20,000). [S19] These coins will be the first to bear national signs. [S20] ### The Great War

The Great War was one of the events that had the greatest impact on the issues, in this context the first minting attempts of the classic period were developed and had a notable impact, limiting and in many cases canceling the issues. [S21] This conflict began in 1839 in Argentinean territory, and that confronted General Fructuoso Rivera and General Manuel Oribe, had moved since 1842 to the territory of the Republic. [S22] General Manuel Oribe burst into Uruguayan territory and reached the city of Montevideo, laying siege to the capital, which became known as the Siege of Montevideo. [S23] Once this siege was installed, two governments were declared; on the one hand, the so-called Defense Government, led by Rivera and installed in the city (until May 13, 1843, when Joaquín Suárez took over as president), and the Cerrito Government, led by Oribe, who claimed the presidency in Cerrito de la Victoria. [S24] ## First national minting

Although the law authorizing this minting dates back to 1839, the first works to carry it out date from May 8, 1840, date on which the engraver Agustín Jouve presents a proposal to the Executive Power to carry out this activity. [S25] The Executive Power quickly accepted the engraver's proposal, since it was very convenient for the State, which took place on May 9 of that same year. [S26] Immediately Agustín Jouve began the work but encountered many problems such as, for example, the shortage of copper and its high price in the market at the time. [S27] To solve the problem and start with the issue, the State agrees to a proposal from Jouve to indemnify him 32.5% over the costs agreed in the initial proposal. [S28] In spite of this, only $500 were minted, which were delivered in two batches, one of $400 on October 3 and the other on October 7, 1840, in violation of the contract that established an amount of $20,000. [S29] These coins were quickly put into circulation by the government on October 15, 1840. [S30] This date was declared "National Numismatic Day" in 1990 by decision of the Executive Power to remember this important event in the history of Uruguay. [S31] These works were carried out in a small workshop owned by Jouve, which was called "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" and was located at 300 25 de Mayo Street. [S32] ### Characteristics of the minted pieces (5 and 20 cent. [S33] of 1840)

| 5 cent. [S34] | Law N.° 208 of June 20, 1839 | 7,1 g | 5,3 - 5,3 grams | Copper | 24 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve | 6.000 (approx.) |
| 20 cent. [S35] | 28,7 g | 26,5 - 27,8 grams | 37 mm | 18.500 (approx.) |

* The 5 cent. [S36] coin was popularly known as "*cinquiño*", coming from the Portuguese term *Cinquinho*, which corresponded to a silver coin of King Manuel of Portugal with a value of 5 reis.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

## Casa de Moneda de Montevideo

The *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* or *Casa de Moneda Nacional* was the institution in charge of the official issuance of coins in the Oriental Republic of Uruguay from 1843 to 1855, although the activity was interrupted on several occasions.

[S94] On June 24, 1854, Laws No. [S95] 414 and 418 were enacted authorizing the minting of gold coins of 10, 20 and 40 reales together with coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of copper. [S96] The minting in gold was never carried out, while in copper only coins of 5 and 20 centésimos were issued, bearing the years 1854 and 1855. [S97] #### Issue 5 and 20 cent. [S98] of 1854

## Assays and mintmark

None of the coins minted in the Classical Period bear a mark that identifies their mint (mint mark). [S108] Only one assay minted for a value of 40 reales in 1854, on the reverse of which there is the imprint of an Mº that would identify the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S109] The assays made in this mint are detailed below. [S110] ### 1840, 5 cents

There are very few known copies of this piece, in which the coin blanks used for its minting are thicker than the rest and its weight is very close to the legal weight. [S111] This is why some numismatists maintain (based on the few copies) that it is an assay, while others (based on the weight of the piece) maintain that it is one of the first minted and that the coin blanks were reduced to economize its production. [S112] ### 1843, 20 cents

There is only one specimen in the National Historical Museum, stamped in lead, which corresponds to the first proof of the 20 cent coin issued on the afternoon of December 13, 1843. [S113] ### 1854, 40 reales

Law Nº 414 of June 24, 1854 established the minting of gold coins of 40 reales (in addition to 10 and 20 reales), which was never carried out. [S114] However, very few of these coins were minted, with a module of 22 mm and a weight of 7 grams. [S115] These are the only pieces to bear the mint mark (Mº). [S116] ## End of the classical period

The classic period culminated with the definitive closing of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which took place at the beginning of the second half of 1855, and from then on, all Uruguayan coins were minted in foreign mints. [S117] During this period, 328,500 copper pieces were minted and only 1,000 silver pieces corresponding to the *Peso de Sitio* were minted; no gold coins were minted. [S118] Of this number of pieces, only a very small number have been minted up to the 21st century, and in the case of some variants, only one specimen is known, making them the most coveted coins of the Uruguayan monetary system, not only because of their scarcity, but also because of their great historical value.
chunk_list:
[S16] These measures were not enough to alleviate the shortage situation, despite the fact that the number of coins issued was considerable (2 million), and led the Government to take new measures in 1839 by means of Law No. [S17] 208 of June 20. [S18] This law creates a new monetary system in which the *Peso* or *Patacón* is divided into 8 reales and each one of them into one hundred centésimos (a system that will last until 1862) and authorizes the issuance of coins of 5 and 20 centésimos (for an amount of $20,000). [S19] These coins will be the first to bear national signs. [S20] ### The Great War

The Great War was one of the events that had the greatest impact on the issues, in this context the first minting attempts of the classic period were developed and had a notable impact, limiting and in many cases canceling the issues. [S21] This conflict began in 1839 in Argentinean territory, and that confronted General Fructuoso Rivera and General Manuel Oribe, had moved since 1842 to the territory of the Republic. [S22] General Manuel Oribe burst into Uruguayan territory and reached the city of Montevideo, laying siege to the capital, which became known as the Siege of Montevideo. [S23] Once this siege was installed, two governments were declared; on the one hand, the so-called Defense Government, led by Rivera and installed in the city (until May 13, 1843, when Joaquín Suárez took over as president), and the Cerrito Government, led by Oribe, who claimed the presidency in Cerrito de la Victoria. [S24] ## First national minting

Although the law authorizing this minting dates back to 1839, the first works to carry it out date from May 8, 1840, date on which the engraver Agustín Jouve presents a proposal to the Executive Power to carry out this activity. [S25] The Executive Power quickly accepted the engraver's proposal, since it was very convenient for the State, which took place on May 9 of that same year. [S26] Immediately Agustín Jouve began the work but encountered many problems such as, for example, the shortage of copper and its high price in the market at the time. [S27] To solve the problem and start with the issue, the State agrees to a proposal from Jouve to indemnify him 32.5% over the costs agreed in the initial proposal. [S28] In spite of this, only $500 were minted, which were delivered in two batches, one of $400 on October 3 and the other on October 7, 1840, in violation of the contract that established an amount of $20,000. [S29] These coins were quickly put into circulation by the government on October 15, 1840. [S30] This date was declared "National Numismatic Day" in 1990 by decision of the Executive Power to remember this important event in the history of Uruguay. [S31] These works were carried out in a small workshop owned by Jouve, which was called "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" and was located at 300 25 de Mayo Street. [S32] ### Characteristics of the minted pieces (5 and 20 cent. [S33] of 1840)

## Casa de Moneda de Montevideo

The *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* or *Casa de Moneda Nacional* was the institution in charge of the official issuance of coins in the Oriental Republic of Uruguay from 1843 to 1855, although the activity was interrupted on several occasions.

[S93] In 1854 the National Mint was again established (but this time in the Government Fort) and Don Juan Gard was appointed as Director, with Don Agustín Rivero as engraver and Don Francisco Didión as assayer. [S94] On June 24, 1854, Laws No. [S95] 414 and 418 were enacted authorizing the minting of gold coins of 10, 20 and 40 reales together with coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of copper. [S96] The minting in gold was never carried out, while in copper only coins of 5 and 20 centésimos were issued, bearing the years 1854 and 1855. [S97] #### Issue 5 and 20 cent. [S98] of 1854

* The 5 cent. [S102] piece has the peculiarity that the front shows the number 4 of the year 1854 "Forced", this would lead to the conclusion that the stamps used in 1840 or 1844 were used, but these do not have the same characteristics, being then a mystery this detail. [S103] * Pieces of 20 cents with date 1854 were minted in 1855 once the production of these last ones was finished, being identical to the ones stamped in the previous year. ## Assays and mintmark

None of the coins minted in the Classical Period bear a mark that identifies their mint (mint mark). [S108] Only one assay minted for a value of 40 reales in 1854, on the reverse of which there is the imprint of an Mº that would identify the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S109] The assays made in this mint are detailed below. [S110] ### 1840, 5 cents

There are very few known copies of this piece, in which the coin blanks used for its minting are thicker than the rest and its weight is very close to the legal weight. [S111] This is why some numismatists maintain (based on the few copies) that it is an assay, while others (based on the weight of the piece) maintain that it is one of the first minted and that the coin blanks were reduced to economize its production. qa_pairs.question: What evidence in the source suggests that the 1840 and 1854 coin issuances were influenced by both economic constraints and political instability, and how did these factors affect the design and circulation of the coins?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The 1840 coin issuance faced economic constraints due to a shortage of copper and its high market price, forcing the State to indemnify the engraver Agustín Jouve 32.5% over initial costs. Despite this, only $500 worth of coins were minted instead of the planned $20,000, highlighting resource limitations.<cite>[S26][S27][S28][S29]</cite></statement> <statement>Political instability, including the Siege of Montevideo (1842–1843) and the division into competing governments, likely influenced the urgency to mint coins. The 1840 coins were quickly circulated by the government on October 15, 1840, to address economic pressures amid conflict.<cite>[S22][S23][S29]</cite></statement> <statement>The 1854 coin issuance reflected economic constraints through the abandonment of gold coin minting (authorized by Law No. 414) and the exclusive production of copper coins. Political instability may have contributed to the delayed and limited production, as seen in the 1854 coins being minted in 1855 and the use of "forced" date stamps on 5-cent coins, possibly due to reused molds.<cite>[S94][S96][S102][S104]</cite></statement> <statement>Design changes, such as the 1840 coins being the first to bear national signs (S19) and the 1854 coins’ standardized weights and modules, suggest efforts to assert national identity and control during periods of instability. However, economic limitations led to variations in coin blanks and production quantities, as noted in the 1840 assays and 1854 copper-only minting.<cite>[S19][S111][S99][S107]</cite></statement>

[S114] However, very few of these coins were minted, with a module of 22 mm and a weight of 7 grams. [S115] These are the only pieces to bear the mint mark (Mº). [S116] ## End of the classical period

The classic period culminated with the definitive closing of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which took place at the beginning of the second half of 1855, and from then on, all Uruguayan coins were minted in foreign mints. [S117] During this period, 328,500 copper pieces were minted and only 1,000 silver pieces corresponding to the *Peso de Sitio* were minted; no gold coins were minted. [S118] Of this number of pieces, only a very small number have been minted up to the 21st century, and in the case of some variants, only one specimen is known, making them the most coveted coins of the Uruguayan monetary system, not only because of their scarcity, but also because of their great historical value.

qa_pairs.question: How do the assays and mint marks mentioned in the source, particularly the 1854 40 reales assay, contribute to our understanding of the technical and administrative practices of the Classical Monetary System in Uruguay?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The assays and mint marks, particularly the 1854 40 reales assay, provide critical insights into the technical and administrative practices of Uruguay's Classical Monetary System. The absence of mint marks on most coins during the Classical Period, except for the 1854 40 reales assay, highlights the limited standardization of identification practices, while the presence of the Mº imprint on this specific assay indicates a deliberate effort to associate the coin with the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* [S108][S109][S116]. This suggests administrative control over minting operations and quality assurance, as assays were likely used to verify compliance with legal weight and metal standards [S110]. The 1854 40 reales assay also reflects technical experimentation, as it was part of a law authorizing gold coins that were never fully minted, yet surviving specimens with unique characteristics (e.g., 22 mm module, 7 grams weight) demonstrate precision in production [S114][S115]. These details reveal both the challenges of resource management (e.g., copper shortages) and the procedural rigor in minting, even during periods of limited capacity [S26][S28].<cite>[S108][S109][S110][S114][S115][S116]</cite></statement><statement>The 1854 40 reales assay further underscores the administrative complexity of the period, as it was tied to legal frameworks like Law No. 414, which mandated gold coinage but faced practical constraints, such as the lack of gold reserves or technical capacity [S114]. The assay’s role in testing minting processes aligns with broader practices seen in earlier issues, such as the 1840 5-cent coin, where discrepancies in weight and blanks sparked debates over whether they were test pieces or cost-cutting measures [S111][S112]. This duality—between experimental assays and mass production—illustrates the interplay of technical innovation and administrative limitations in Uruguay’s monetary system [S110][S111].<cite>[S110][S111][S112][S114]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What were the key historical and economic challenges that influenced the development of the Classical Monetary System in Uruguay between 1840 and 1855, and how did these factors shape the efforts to establish a national currency?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The development of the Classical Monetary System in Uruguay between 1840 and 1855 was shaped by significant historical and economic challenges, including a chaotic economy, the absence of a unified currency, and the prolonged civil war known as the Great War. These factors created instability, forcing efforts to establish a national currency despite ongoing difficulties.<cite>[S3]</cite></statement> <statement>Economic problems and the lack of a national monetary policy were compounded by the circulation of multiple foreign currencies, such as those from Spain, Portugal, the British Empire, the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata, and Brazil, which persisted even after Uruguay's independence. This fragmentation hindered the creation of a cohesive monetary system.<cite>[S4]</cite></statement> <statement>The provisional government after independence (1828) initially allowed all existing currencies to circulate, delaying formal monetary reforms. However, by 1829, restrictions on foreign copper coins were introduced, though precious metals remained in use until 1893, reflecting the struggle to replace foreign currency with a national alternative.<cite>[S9][S11]</cite></statement> <statement>Efforts to address these challenges included temporary measures like the 1831 "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires" currency, which aimed to stabilize commerce after the withdrawal of foreign copper coins. These initiatives highlight the urgency of establishing a national currency amid economic instability.<cite>[S14][S15]</cite></statement> <statement>The persistent economic difficulties and social instability of the new state, as noted in the passage, made it nearly impossible to implement a lasting monetary policy. This context underscores the incremental and reactive nature of Uruguay's efforts to develop a Classical Monetary System during this period.<cite>[S8]</cite></statement>

[S1] Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay


# Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay



The **Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay** includes the coins minted by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay between the years 1840 and 1855 in the national territory. [S2] These coins were minted entirely within the city of Montevideo, first at the "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" owned by a French artisan named Agustín Jouve and later at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* (Montevideo Mint) or *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, which was created for this purpose. [S3] This period in Uruguayan numismatics was immersed in a historical context full of economic problems, a non-existent currency, an economy practically in chaos and a civil war that lasted for years (the Great War). [S4] In spite of these difficulties, several attempts were made to mint a coin that would bear national signs and would be able to put an end to the prevailing chaos, given that up to that moment the currency of all the different regimes that had exercised power in the territory had been in circulation: the Crown of Spain, the Crown of Portugal, the British Empire, the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata and, finally, the Empire of Brazil. [S5] The first national coins were minted in 1839, in the workshop of the engraver Agustín Jouve, followed by the series minted in the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* until 1855, date from which the first coins were minted in foreign mints, thus culminating the classic period of Uruguayan numismatics. [S6] During this period magnificent coins were issued, among them the *Peso del Sitio* and the *Sol de cabellera*, all of which are currently museum pieces or are part of the most important collections in the country, each of them being highly coveted by collectors. [S7] ## Historical context

Since the birth of the new Republic, on August 27, 1828, there were several attempts to create a monetary system that would solve the problem of the circulating currencies in the territory and define a national monetary system with national signs. [S8] However, the economic difficulties of the time and the social situation of the new State made it almost impossible to install an economic-monetary policy that would put an end to the daily difficulties of commerce. [S9] Once independence was achieved, the provisional government of General José Rondeau (October 4, 1828) did not take any monetary measure and allowed the circulation of all the currencies existing in the country at the date of assumption. [S10] The first decisions regarding the monetary aspect were taken in 1829, year in which it was prohibited the introduction of all copper coins coming from abroad into the territory of the Republic. [S11] However, precious metal coins (gold and silver) continued to circulate until 1893 (accepted until then for their intrinsic value), when their circulation was definitively prohibited. [S12] With the arrival of the first Constitutional President of the Republic, General Fructuoso Rivera, important measures continued to be taken, ordering in 1831 the withdrawal of all foreign copper currency. [S13] As a result of these measures, the city suffered a serious lack of foreign currency, so the government began to look for a quick solution to supply the needs of commerce. [S14] A solution to this situation was found by means of the law of March 14, 1831, which provided for the issuance of the currency known as "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires" for half of its written value. [S15] These coins with a value of one tenth of a real were the first coins issued by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay.

# Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay



The **Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay** includes the coins minted by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay between the years 1840 and 1855 in the national territory. [S2] These coins were minted entirely within the city of Montevideo, first at the "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" owned by a French artisan named Agustín Jouve and later at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* (Montevideo Mint) or *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, which was created for this purpose. [S3] This period in Uruguayan numismatics was immersed in a historical context full of economic problems, a non-existent currency, an economy practically in chaos and a civil war that lasted for years (the Great War). [S4] In spite of these difficulties, several attempts were made to mint a coin that would bear national signs and would be able to put an end to the prevailing chaos, given that up to that moment the currency of all the different regimes that had exercised power in the territory had been in circulation: the Crown of Spain, the Crown of Portugal, the British Empire, the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata and, finally, the Empire of Brazil. [S5] The first national coins were minted in 1839, in the workshop of the engraver Agustín Jouve, followed by the series minted in the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* until 1855, date from which the first coins were minted in foreign mints, thus culminating the classic period of Uruguayan numismatics. [S6] During this period magnificent coins were issued, among them the *Peso del Sitio* and the *Sol de cabellera*, all of which are currently museum pieces or are part of the most important collections in the country, each of them being highly coveted by collectors. [S7] ## Historical context

Since the birth of the new Republic, on August 27, 1828, there were several attempts to create a monetary system that would solve the problem of the circulating currencies in the territory and define a national monetary system with national signs. [S8] However, the economic difficulties of the time and the social situation of the new State made it almost impossible to install an economic-monetary policy that would put an end to the daily difficulties of commerce. [S9] Once independence was achieved, the provisional government of General José Rondeau (October 4, 1828) did not take any monetary measure and allowed the circulation of all the currencies existing in the country at the date of assumption. [S10] The first decisions regarding the monetary aspect were taken in 1829, year in which it was prohibited the introduction of all copper coins coming from abroad into the territory of the Republic. [S11] However, precious metal coins (gold and silver) continued to circulate until 1893 (accepted until then for their intrinsic value), when their circulation was definitively prohibited. [S12] With the arrival of the first Constitutional President of the Republic, General Fructuoso Rivera, important measures continued to be taken, ordering in 1831 the withdrawal of all foreign copper currency. [S13] As a result of these measures, the city suffered a serious lack of foreign currency, so the government began to look for a quick solution to supply the needs of commerce. [S14] A solution to this situation was found by means of the law of March 14, 1831, which provided for the issuance of the currency known as "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires" for half of its written value. [S15] These coins with a value of one tenth of a real were the first coins issued by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay.

qa_pairs.question: Why were the *Peso del Sitio* and *Sol de cabellera* significant in the context of Uruguayan numismatics, and what does their current status indicate about their historical value?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The *Peso del Sitio* and *Sol de cabellera* were significant in Uruguayan numismatics as they were part of the classical monetary system established during a period of economic chaos, civil war, and attempts to create a national currency amid conflicting circulating currencies from foreign regimes. This historical context is detailed in [S3] and [S4].<cite>[S3][S4]</cite></statement><statement>Their current status as museum pieces or prized collections highlights their historical value, as they are described as "highly coveted by collectors" and preserved as significant artifacts of Uruguay's numismatic heritage, as noted in [S6].<cite>[S6]</cite></statement>

[S1] Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay


# Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay



The **Classical Monetary System of the Oriental Republic of Uruguay** includes the coins minted by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay between the years 1840 and 1855 in the national territory. [S2] These coins were minted entirely within the city of Montevideo, first at the "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" owned by a French artisan named Agustín Jouve and later at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* (Montevideo Mint) or *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, which was created for this purpose. [S3] This period in Uruguayan numismatics was immersed in a historical context full of economic problems, a non-existent currency, an economy practically in chaos and a civil war that lasted for years (the Great War). [S4] In spite of these difficulties, several attempts were made to mint a coin that would bear national signs and would be able to put an end to the prevailing chaos, given that up to that moment the currency of all the different regimes that had exercised power in the territory had been in circulation: the Crown of Spain, the Crown of Portugal, the British Empire, the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata and, finally, the Empire of Brazil. [S5] The first national coins were minted in 1839, in the workshop of the engraver Agustín Jouve, followed by the series minted in the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* until 1855, date from which the first coins were minted in foreign mints, thus culminating the classic period of Uruguayan numismatics. [S6] During this period magnificent coins were issued, among them the *Peso del Sitio* and the *Sol de cabellera*, all of which are currently museum pieces or are part of the most important collections in the country, each of them being highly coveted by collectors. [S7] ## Historical context

Since the birth of the new Republic, on August 27, 1828, there were several attempts to create a monetary system that would solve the problem of the circulating currencies in the territory and define a national monetary system with national signs. [S8] However, the economic difficulties of the time and the social situation of the new State made it almost impossible to install an economic-monetary policy that would put an end to the daily difficulties of commerce. [S9] Once independence was achieved, the provisional government of General José Rondeau (October 4, 1828) did not take any monetary measure and allowed the circulation of all the currencies existing in the country at the date of assumption. [S10] The first decisions regarding the monetary aspect were taken in 1829, year in which it was prohibited the introduction of all copper coins coming from abroad into the territory of the Republic. [S11] However, precious metal coins (gold and silver) continued to circulate until 1893 (accepted until then for their intrinsic value), when their circulation was definitively prohibited. [S12] With the arrival of the first Constitutional President of the Republic, General Fructuoso Rivera, important measures continued to be taken, ordering in 1831 the withdrawal of all foreign copper currency. [S13] As a result of these measures, the city suffered a serious lack of foreign currency, so the government began to look for a quick solution to supply the needs of commerce. [S14] A solution to this situation was found by means of the law of March 14, 1831, which provided for the issuance of the currency known as "Tenths of the city of Buenos Aires" for half of its written value. [S15] These coins with a value of one tenth of a real were the first coins issued by the Oriental Republic of Uruguay.

[S16] These measures were not enough to alleviate the shortage situation, despite the fact that the number of coins issued was considerable (2 million), and led the Government to take new measures in 1839 by means of Law No. [S17] 208 of June 20. [S18] This law creates a new monetary system in which the *Peso* or *Patacón* is divided into 8 reales and each one of them into one hundred centésimos (a system that will last until 1862) and authorizes the issuance of coins of 5 and 20 centésimos (for an amount of $20,000). [S19] These coins will be the first to bear national signs. [S20] ### The Great War

The Great War was one of the events that had the greatest impact on the issues, in this context the first minting attempts of the classic period were developed and had a notable impact, limiting and in many cases canceling the issues. [S21] This conflict began in 1839 in Argentinean territory, and that confronted General Fructuoso Rivera and General Manuel Oribe, had moved since 1842 to the territory of the Republic. [S22] General Manuel Oribe burst into Uruguayan territory and reached the city of Montevideo, laying siege to the capital, which became known as the Siege of Montevideo. [S23] Once this siege was installed, two governments were declared; on the one hand, the so-called Defense Government, led by Rivera and installed in the city (until May 13, 1843, when Joaquín Suárez took over as president), and the Cerrito Government, led by Oribe, who claimed the presidency in Cerrito de la Victoria. [S24] ## First national minting

Although the law authorizing this minting dates back to 1839, the first works to carry it out date from May 8, 1840, date on which the engraver Agustín Jouve presents a proposal to the Executive Power to carry out this activity. [S25] The Executive Power quickly accepted the engraver's proposal, since it was very convenient for the State, which took place on May 9 of that same year. [S26] Immediately Agustín Jouve began the work but encountered many problems such as, for example, the shortage of copper and its high price in the market at the time. [S27] To solve the problem and start with the issue, the State agrees to a proposal from Jouve to indemnify him 32.5% over the costs agreed in the initial proposal. [S28] In spite of this, only $500 were minted, which were delivered in two batches, one of $400 on October 3 and the other on October 7, 1840, in violation of the contract that established an amount of $20,000. [S29] These coins were quickly put into circulation by the government on October 15, 1840. [S30] This date was declared "National Numismatic Day" in 1990 by decision of the Executive Power to remember this important event in the history of Uruguay. [S31] These works were carried out in a small workshop owned by Jouve, which was called "*Taller y Armería Jouve*" and was located at 300 25 de Mayo Street. [S32] ### Characteristics of the minted pieces (5 and 20 cent. [S33] of 1840)

| Minting in 1840 | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Value | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 5 cent. [S34] | Law N.° 208 of June 20, 1839 | 7,1 g | 5,3 - 5,3 grams | Copper | 24 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve | 6.000 (approx.) |
| 20 cent. [S35] | 28,7 g | 26,5 - 27,8 grams | 37 mm | 18.500 (approx.) |

* The 5 cent. [S36] coin was popularly known as "*cinquiño*", coming from the Portuguese term *Cinquinho*, which corresponded to a silver coin of King Manuel of Portugal with a value of 5 reis.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

## Casa de Moneda de Montevideo

The *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo* or *Casa de Moneda Nacional* was the institution in charge of the official issuance of coins in the Oriental Republic of Uruguay from 1843 to 1855, although the activity was interrupted on several occasions.

[S37] It was created in order to comply with Laws No. [S38] 254 and No. [S39] 255 of December 13, 1843, which empowered the Government to issue coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of real (copper) and Half and One *Peso Fuerte* (silver). [S40] The same day these laws were enacted, the first tests were carried out, minting coins of 20 hundredths of a real. [S41] In spite of this, the institution was officially inaugurated on February 2, 1844, by the then Political and Police Chief of Montevideo, Andrés Lamas, installing itself in a small workshop in the building of the Police Headquarters of the city called *Casa Central de Policía*. [S42] ### First period of issues by the Casa de Monedas

There are two distinct stages in the first period of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which are detailed below. [S43] ### First stage

This stage began with the minting of a 20 centésimos coin on the afternoon of December 13 and lasted until mid-March 1844, when the Mint suspended its activities. [S44] During this period the institution depended on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo and its director was Don Domingo Parpal and minted coins of 20 centésimos of 1843, 5, 20 and 40 centésimos of 1844 in addition to the magnificent piece of the *Peso Fuerte* or *Peso del Sitio*. [S45] All these pieces were made in the workshop located in the *"Casa Central de Policía"*. [S46] #### First issue (20 cent 1843)

Immediately after the promulgation of Law No. [S47] 254 of December 13, 1843, the first trials were carried out by issuing 20 cent coins with the same stamps used by Agustín Jouve in 1839, with the date changed from 1840 to 1843. [S48] The characteristic of these pieces is that since the date was modified, the number 3 appears forced. [S49] These pieces are the first issued by the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S50] | 20 cents of 1843 | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Valoe | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 20 cent. [S51] | N.° 254 of the day December 13, 1843. [S52] | 21,5 grams | 20 - 24,9 grams | Copper | 37 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve (adapted stamps) | 15.000 (approx.) |

* This coin was known by the name of "*Vintén*" which comes from the Portuguese expression "*Vintem*" which corresponds to a coin with the value of 20 réis of copper.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

#### Issue 5, 20, 40 cents of 1844

They were issued throughout the first stage of the Mint. [S53] They were pieces that contributed to give solidity to the development of commerce and helped to put an end to the great shortage of circulating currency that existed in the new Republic. [S54] | **Minting in 1844** | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Value | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 5 cent. [S55] | N.° 254 of the day December 13, 1843. [S56] | 5,38 grams | 5,4 - 5,7 grams | Copper | 24 mm | Smooth | Agustín Jouve | 6.000 (approx.) |
| 20 cent. [S57] | 21,5 grams | 21 grams | 38 mm | 10.000 (approx.) |
| 40 cent. [S58] | 43 grams | 36 - 42 grams | 38 – 42 mm | 65.000 (approx.) |

* Five different mintages are known for the 5 cent. [S59] piece. [S60] * The 40 cent. [S61] coin was the only one minted at the Mint with this value. [S62] For its minting, a number of stamps were used that have not yet been accurately determined, so that more than 20 variants of this piece are known. [S63] One of these variants is known as the "*Sol de Cabellera*", since on the obverse the face of the sun corresponds to a native with long hair. [S64] Due to its great relief, it is very rare to find specimens in good condition, which makes it a very coveted piece by collectors. [S65] #### *Peso del Sitio* or *Peso Fuerte*

[S66] This piece is the only silver coin to be minted at the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S67] This minting was carried out in an extremely reduced number (a little more than 1,000) due to the scarcity of materials. [S68] This shortage of materials (caused by the Siege of Montevideo) could be overcome because materials were collected inside the besieged square. [S69] *Mates*, spoons, light bulbs, spurs, etc., all made of silver, were collected from the citizens, among them Andrés Lamas himself or personalities such as Giuseppe Garibaldi or Isidoro de María.ᵖᵃᵍᵉⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ The collected silver, naturally impure, product of the different qualities of silver collected, was analyzed by the expert chemist Professor Julio Antonio Lenoble, who classified the material with a fine 10 1/2 dineros (0.875). [S70] #### Characteristics of the *Peso del Sitio*

| ***Peso del Sitio* o *Peso Fuerte*** | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Image | | Value | Characteristics | | | | | | | |
| Front | Back | Law | Legal weight | Real weight | Metal | Module | Edge | Engraver | Amount minted |
| 1 peso. [S71] | N.° 254 of December 13, 1843. [S72] | 27 grams | 27 grams | Silver, fine 10 1/2 (*dinero*) | 39 mm | *Cordoncillo* | Agustín Jouve | 1.000 (approx.) |

* Some pieces minted on coins from other countries are known. [S73] * This piece would circulate only in Montevideo since on February 15, 1844, from his headquarters in the Cerrito de la Victoria, General Manuel Oribe (Chief of the forces that besieged Montevideo) prohibits the circulation throughout the territory of the Republic. [S74] It is, without a doubt, one of the most beautiful coins of the Classical Monetary. [S75] It was minted with similar characteristics to those of a Spanish peso. [S76] It is believed that it was minted more as a commemorative element than for circulation. [S77] This idea is based on the good condition in which the specimens have arrived to our time (although some specimens undoubtedly circulated). [S78] The following is a small passage from a speech made by Andrés Lamas to the President of the Republic, Joaquín Suárez, on the occasion of the inauguration of the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S79] > YOUR EXCELLENCY. [S80] Sir: I have the honor to present to Your Excellency the first silver coin destined for circulation, minted at the *Casa de Moneda Nacional*. [S81] This coin, Mr. [S82] President, is monumental, and this monument is unique to this day on the eastern and western banks of the Rio de la Plata. [S83] This coin is the most finished symbol, Mr. [S84] President, of the National Independence. [S85] In all times and in the public law of all nations, the minting of coins has been the highest prerogative of the Independent Empire. [S86] ### Second stage

The *Casa de Moneda Nacional*, once out of operation, continued to depend on the Political Chief of the city of Montevideo, until May 27, 1844, when it became dependent on the Ministry of Finance (a position held by Andres Lamas). [S87] On September 20, 1844, Andrés Lamas resigned from the Ministry of Finance due to a series of denunciations he received for irregularities committed in the *Casa de Monedas*. [S88] At the head of this ministry would now be Don Santiago Sayago who would order on October 20 the opening of the mint designating Don Juan de Bernade y Mederos as General Director. [S89] The existing stamps were immediately inspected and found to be in very poor condition, so the Director obtained authorization to have new ones engraved. [S90] During this period only 40 cent coins were issued with a date of 1844 (as was seen previously in issue 40 cent of 1844). [S91] This stage of the *Casa de Monedas* lasted until mid-January 1845, when it was definitively closed and the materials of Agustín Jouve used up to that time were returned. [S92] ### Second period of issues by the *Casa de Monedas*

[S93] In 1854 the National Mint was again established (but this time in the Government Fort) and Don Juan Gard was appointed as Director, with Don Agustín Rivero as engraver and Don Francisco Didión as assayer. [S94] On June 24, 1854, Laws No. [S95] 414 and 418 were enacted authorizing the minting of gold coins of 10, 20 and 40 reales together with coins of 5, 20 and 40 hundredths of copper. [S96] The minting in gold was never carried out, while in copper only coins of 5 and 20 centésimos were issued, bearing the years 1854 and 1855. [S97] #### Issue 5 and 20 cent. [S98] of 1854

## Assays and mintmark

None of the coins minted in the Classical Period bear a mark that identifies their mint (mint mark). [S108] Only one assay minted for a value of 40 reales in 1854, on the reverse of which there is the imprint of an Mº that would identify the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*. [S109] The assays made in this mint are detailed below. [S110] ### 1840, 5 cents

There are very few known copies of this piece, in which the coin blanks used for its minting are thicker than the rest and its weight is very close to the legal weight. [S111] This is why some numismatists maintain (based on the few copies) that it is an assay, while others (based on the weight of the piece) maintain that it is one of the first minted and that the coin blanks were reduced to economize its production. [S112] ### 1843, 20 cents

There is only one specimen in the National Historical Museum, stamped in lead, which corresponds to the first proof of the 20 cent coin issued on the afternoon of December 13, 1843. [S113] ### 1854, 40 reales

Law Nº 414 of June 24, 1854 established the minting of gold coins of 40 reales (in addition to 10 and 20 reales), which was never carried out. [S114] However, very few of these coins were minted, with a module of 22 mm and a weight of 7 grams. [S115] These are the only pieces to bear the mint mark (Mº). [S116] ## End of the classical period

The classic period culminated with the definitive closing of the *Casa de Moneda de Montevideo*, which took place at the beginning of the second half of 1855, and from then on, all Uruguayan coins were minted in foreign mints. [S117] During this period, 328,500 copper pieces were minted and only 1,000 silver pieces corresponding to the *Peso de Sitio* were minted; no gold coins were minted. [S118] Of this number of pieces, only a very small number have been minted up to the 21st century, and in the case of some variants, only one specimen is known, making them the most coveted coins of the Uruguayan monetary system, not only because of their scarcity, but also because of their great historical value.
